dialogue: Martha...
Ingrid! What a surprise! How did you hear?
I ran into Stella, she told me.
I’m so sorry, I didn’t even know you were sick.
You with your work and me with mine…
It’s true. And I was living in Paris.
I’d heard that. I’ve been reading about you. I know you’ve published another book, and that it’s doing very well.
How are you? I’m sure you’re tired of explaining it to everyone.

It’s cervical cancer. Stage 3. It isn’t operable, but they’re treating me and it looks like I’m not going to die quite yet. I’ve become a guinea pig for an experimental treatment. The results are much better than what the doctors were expecting.
That’s great! You seem in good spirits.
Well, I swing between euphoria and depression.
I’m so sorry.
It’s normal. The doctors warned me… to
Don’t say that!
I was prepared to leave. In fact, when I got the initial diagnosis, I didn’t want any treatment.
I’m glad you changed your mind. Just the thought… you would… and me not knowing…
I realized I really didn’t want to abandon the party just yet, but I truly had gotten used to the idea…
I suppose it’s good to get used to the idea… but without giving up… You’ve been through quite a few wars, remember?
I live with them every day!
Me too. It’s ridiculous that we haven’t seen each other for so long. I promise to visit you until you get bored with me.
Your daughter knows, I guess.
Yes. When I’d first made up my mind to forgo any treatment, I told her and she just said: It’s your choice. Period. As if it were something trivial, something that had nothing to do with her.
How are you two getting along?
What does she do?
She’s doing well. She is an agent for classical musicians.
It might sound horrible, but I don’t feel like she’s my daughter. I’ve fantasized frequently about her being swapped at birth.
What! What are you talking about? She looks just like you. She has your face.
I never interested her as a mother.
Why not?
I was a teenager when I had her. I didn’t
I was lying to her. Of course I knew who he was…
His name was Fred. We dated for a few months before he was drafted and he went to fight, towards the end of Vietnam.
When he came back a year later, he was… somebody different… he was a broken toy…
Does Michelle know this?

She started asking about her father as soon as she could talk, but it’s not something I could explain to a child, right? By puberty, she had already carved out quite an abyss between us. It came to define her adolescence. But, by then, I was no longer there, I was in New York with you, living my life.
I arranged to meet Fred one evening to
I don’t think working in a hospital was the best thing for such a damaged person. It’s the closest thing to war. What he needed was therapy and rehab.

That would have been more sensible, but he wanted to be useful. To ease his conscience… He believed that helping people who were between life and death was the best chance to get back any peace. I could only free him of any responsibility. He left before Michelle was born, he never knew her. He didn’t even call once to ask about her.
When did you tell her?

She was about twelve. She wanted to know where he was living, but I didn’t know anymore. She was so insistent that I tracked down an old friend of his from high school, who told me that Fred had gotten married and had recently died. I asked him for his wife’s number and I called her. I wanted to know what had happened.
She said that they were coming home… after a trip.
Did you tell Michelle all of this?
Yes. I had to give her all the details. I even gave her her father’s wife’s phone number.
You know what… Let’s get you back to bed. You’re tired… we can talk later. You don’t have to tell me now.
No, I have to tell you this. One day, I got a call from Fred’s wife. She asked me for my address, she wanted to send me something…
That’s insane!
Yes.
Hi!
It’s Martha, the nuisance…
You’re not a nuisance. How are you feeling?
Fine, I’m at home.
The hospital has given me a few days off between treatments, so I’m at home.
Well, you’ve got me in the middle of moving.
Oh, then you’re really busy, right?
Well, you know what moving is like, but if you’re feeling lonely I could stop by… We can take a walk through the park.
I might not be quite up for a walk…
Okay… you know what… let me finish what I’m doing and come over.
Thank you, sweetheart, but don’t feel obliged.
These are for you…
You’re a darling. Thank you.
And I brought you a couple of books.
Thank you… You want something to drink?
I’d love some tea. Herbal tea if you have it.
Sure. I’ll put these in a vase. All this is for you. You
Wow, I’ll do my best. I love fruit.
Are you working on something new?

Actually, I am! I’m doing research on the painter Dora Carrington and her intense devotion to the writer Lytton Strachey. Here he is. Strachey was gay, so she married the straight man that he was infatuated with. It’ll be the story of the trio. It isn’t groundbreaking, but I want to see where it takes me. Here you go…

Her work isn’t very well known. Unfortunately for her, there was a more famous painter, the surrealist Leonora Carrington, whose name was obviously very similar to hers. Dora was better known for this deranged love story with Strachey. She devoted seventeen years of her life to him. It’ll be a fictionalized biography, so I’ll make some stuff up too.
I’ve never been able to allow myself that…
Well, I can imagine, you’re a war reporter.
You can’t show your emotions. You have to block them out so you could do your job and stay present, in the middle of whatever hell.
The mere idea of it gives me chills.
You have to separate the emotional from the professional.
Maybe I should write about you and not Carrington.
I don’t think you’d enjoy writing about illnesses and treatments.
You’re wrong.
I’m just a journalist, addicted to wars and adrenaline.
And you think that’s nothing?
Oh, really?!
Naturally, I never published it.
It was during the war in Iraq. The last
Are you sure this is the right way?
Mhmm… and her connection to Virginia Woolf, whom Strachey also pursued romantically.
What a group! I so admire their freedom.
Strachey died of stomach cancer eighteen years after meeting Dora. And Dora survived him by barely two months before she shot herself in the stomach.
She was only thirty-eight…
I’m struck by the symmetry of that kind of gesture… His stomach cancer and her shooting herself in the stomach.
I know… it struck me too.
Maybe Virginia saw a kind of warning in Carrington’s death, a mirror that reflected her.
Yes. It's as if the two of them, no matter what happened, were fated.
Do you think I’m fated too?
No! Of course not! I’ve never known anyone more alive than you.
Next week I’m starting a new experimental immunotherapy treatment. They’ve already tried it and it seems to work well with cases of cervical cancer.
Well that’s great news! Let me know when I can come and visit you, okay?
I will…Talking of symmetry… do you remember Damian Cunningham?
How could I forget?! I inherited him from you.
The shared lover. I have to say, I felt terrible when you got together after I’d been with him.
Okay, we didn’t share him exactly, because you had already broken up and you were out of the country.
I would never go back with him! And to tell the truth I was never faithful to him. But he was a passionate, and enthusiastic lover… And I hope he was for
I had no complaints.
Hi. What is it?
It hasn’t worked, I’ve got metastases in my liver and in my bones.
I should have followed my first instinct and not put myself through this torture. The vomiting, the diarrhea, the fatigue… just to end up like this… I should never have given in to false hopes.
What does the doctor say? Tell me.
That I could live for months, maybe a year… He wants me to continue the treatment even though it looks hopeless!
Maybe it will work this time!

I don’t want to wallow in self-pity. I’m also no stoic, I’m sorry. I don’t want to go through excruciating pain. You can’t be self-possessed if you’re in agony, you can’t think straight, you can think of only one thing… the fucking cancer.

I’ve always taken care of my health, and now I regret it. The doctor says I have a strong heart. What does that mean? That my body will keep fighting, that I’ll have to suffer and suffer up to my last breath?
I don’t know… I don’t know how to help you… I’m so sorry.
I think I deserve a good death… or at least one without convulsions in my last moments. Going out with a little bit of dignity, clean and dry. But I know I’m asking too much…
Bring it on.
I’ll end up turning into a junkie. I am one already, I guess.
It’s okay, really.
Are you still here?
Yes.
Should I tell ask them to bring your dinner? Are you hungry?
No. Ingrid, do you think I need to say goodbye to my closest friends?
I think you should do whatever you want to do.
I just want some peace and quiet.
Have
Vaguely.
“The snow is falling, falling on the lonely churchyard, falling faintly through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead…”
It’s late… I should be going…
Thank you.
I’ll see you tomorrow.
There’s still a half an hour before the movie starts. Shall we go in and get our seats before the rush?
No… I want to talk to you about something.
Okay.
I will not go out in mortifying anguish.
I don’t know what to say.
I’m hoping/I hope you’ll say yes.
Yes to what?
To my asking you to help me.
To help you what?

I’ve faced death several times, but I’ve was always been accompanied, us reporters formed a kind of mobile family. This is another war, I’m not afraid of it, but like the other times I faced death, I don’t want to be alone, Ingrid. I’m just asking you… to be in the next room.
I think we should go get our seats…
Yeah, sure, but I prefer to go on talking to you, if you don’t mind.
Okay… Do you know when you want to do this?

Not exactly… within a month…? Before I start to deteriorate and you don’t recognize me… During these first weeks, I'll still be reasonably well, that's why I want to do it soon. The doctors think I’m going to return to continue with the treatment. So it’s best if they don’t suspect anything.
Do you know where you want to do it?
I don’t want to be at home, or go back to someplace where I was happy in the past. We must never return to the places where we were truly happy because we ruin the good memories of the first time...
I know what that is…
I think it will be easier for me to let myself go if I’m not surrounded by
Do you need my help finding a place, or getting you settled in?
No, no… I can do that myself. What I need is someone to be there with me, in the room next door.
Wouldn’t you prefer someone that you’re closer to?
We’re very close.
Yes, we are. Of course we are… Oh my God! Yes! We’re very close! But we didn’t see each other for years… What about Stella, Vanessa, Maggie… You’ve all been friends since you were kids.

I admit it. I thought of them first. I asked all three of them, and they were all horrified. They all said no. They understood it, but they said they could never be a part of helping me take my own life. Absolutely not.
What about your daughter?
It wouldn’t be fair to her, I’ve been an absent mother. I don’t want to impose my dying on her.
But… you could consult her, let her be part of it…
We’re two strangers, Ingrid. She made that clear when I told her my doubts about the treatment. It’s your choice, she said. And she’s right.
Right.

No matter what, people want you to keep on fighting. This is how we’ve been taught to see cancer: as a fight between patient and disease, which is to say between good and evil . If you survive, well you’re a hero. And If you lose… well, perhaps you didn’t fight hard enough. People don’t want to hear the words “terminal” or “incurable”. They call that defeatist talk.
People should understand that this is my
Are you completely sure you’re ready?
Totally… since the first diagnosis.
You know that I have a terrible fear of death…
I know. I read your book. That’s why I didn’t ask you first. But you understand me, don’t you?
Of course. I do. And I envy you. You’re in control of your life.
I only need you to accompany me on the days leading up to it, as if we were on vacation. I just need to know that, when it happens, there’ll be someone in the next room.
It terrifies me, Martha.
I understand that.
You’re much stronger than you think… Anyway, I had to try.
I can’t answer you right now, Martha, but I promise I’ll think about it. Right now I’m too confused and too terrified.
I understand… it’s so sudden… it’s disconcerting. I’ll think of someone.
I wasn’t too much?
No, no!
Hello, Ingrid.
Hi, I’ve made up my mind.
Come on in… The owner’s a jewelry designer… she’s a friend of mine, so I don’t pay much rent.
Better, much better since you said yes.
Where are you? Are you at home?
Yeah, I’m watering the plants.
I do… but today I felt like doing it. And I’m enjoying it!
Good… Have you decided where we’re going?

That’s why I called… It’s near Woodstock, about two hours from the city. The owners travel constantly and rent out the house to pay for their trips. It looks fantastic, it’s a bit expensive, but, hey, the occasion calls for it.
How long do you… think…?
I rented it for a month. That should give me more than enough time.
A month?!
Yeah, my blood count’s low and I have to
According to the map, we go up these steps to enter the house.
Wow! It’s so beautiful!
It’s so much more beautiful than the photographs!
I don’t think they would have left it here. But it’s a very good copy, it looks real.
Do you hear them?! How wonderful!
Do you mind if I take this one?
No! Of course not. It’s your house.
Oh, this one’s a little small… I’m going to look downstairs.
Okay.
I’m going to take this one, okay?!
Very good!
You don’t mind that I’m not in the room next door?
I can hear you breathe… And yell.
Let me help you unpack.
Thank you, I’ll unpack it later. You’re not my caretaker, Ingrid. You’re my guest.
Okay, then I’ll unpack my things.
What's wrong, honey?
You won’t believe it…!
I forgot it!
Forgot what?
The pill, the euthanasia pill! I brought all the others! We have to go back now.
Of course. We can go first thing in the morning.
No, not tomorrow. We have to go now!
Okay. Let’s go…

Buying another pill would be extremely complicated. I have a friend who knows a mathematician who found it on the Dark Web. It’s all very sordid, not to mention totally illegal. It’s scary knowing that all that exists, right behind our computer screens… I felt like a real criminal.
I never thought I’d be back here, that I’d see this wonderful skyline again. Life always surprises you.
Well, let’s get to work. I’ll start in the kitchen.
Don’t worry. I’ll help you find it.
Just think of the places where you usually hide things.
This is the first thing I’ve ever hidden. The only thing I remember is that I put it in an envelope.
I’ll start in your office.
Yes. Where did I put it?
I found an envelope.
That’s it!
A drawer in your desk. The key was in the lock and I opened it.
How could I have forgotten it? I even left the key in it!?
You were going to take it and, at the last minute, you forgot. It isn’t so unusual.
Thank you.
What a strange sensation! It’s like being back at home after I’m dead.
Don’t say that. It’s too soon for you to be referring to yourself as a ghost.
Thank you.
Thank you, and forgive me for all this hassle. I’m so sorry, really.
What a great place to return to.
Maybe leaving the pill behind… was a kind of sign? Maybe you’re not as ready as you think…
I told you to never say that to me.
I don’t remember you telling me that.
I think I’ve told you so many things… That’s the problem with chemo brain.
Then how can you trust this decision that has brought us here? How do you know that isn’t also chemo brain too?
I’ve left the pill in the top drawer of the bedside table. If I forget, which I don’t think I will, you will remind me. And I prefer to not talk about this anymore.
It concerns me too, don’t you think?

Sure. Of course. I’ll leave a signed letter for the police telling them everything. Including the name of the pill and how I got it. Your name won’t appear anywhere. All you have to do is to say that you knew nothing, and
I know it’s difficult. Just think we’re on vacation. You can write, we can come and go…
I don’t think I’ll be able to concentrate. And if I write about myself, you might show up somewhere… and I don’t want to do that.
I don’t want that either. It would complicate your life if the police investigate…
But I’m not going to do it.
Wait until I’m dead.
I promise.
I’d like to find a gym to go to a couple times a week. I’m the only one of the two who eats and I don’t want to gain ten pounds while you waste away.
Give me a chance! I’ll catch up with you! Look at me! I'm eating.
I’ve practically held death in my hands and I never imagined it would be something
I’m making breakfast. Would you like some toast?
Coffee first.
Help yourself. It’s already made. There’s cereal and juice as well. Whatever you want. The coffee pot is full.
What makes you think that I need one! The last thing I need is to be a drug addict!

My behavior yesterday was unacceptable. I completely understand that it drove you crazy. I’ll try not to let it happen again, but in my current state I can’t make any promises. So, just in case, I’ve left a medium range sedative, in this drawer. If you find me unbearable, you can take one and you can relax.
I might take you up on that/I could have used one last night. You’re one of a kind, Martha. You really are.
I’ve made a list of stuff to buy. We need a few things.
I don’t think so.
Do you want to come to the store with me?
Maybe another day. It feels so nice here, I think I’d like to stay. If you don’t mind…
No, of course not. I also found a gym that isn’t too far away.
That’s great. I think it’s a very good idea.
Okay… I’ll have my phone with me if you need anything…
Thanks, love.
Hello. I was hoping I could use the gym today.
Oh, look at that. Oh, I´ve been meaning to read this book… What a wonderful title! Erotic Vagrancy…
Do you want to buy it?
I won’t have time to finish it.
Oh, look. Martha Gellhorn. The View from the Ground.
She wrote you can only love one war, afterwards you simply do your duty.
Which one was yours?
Bosnia, without a doubt. The fight to survive by the Bosnian people against a perfectly equipped army stole the hearts of all of us who witnessed the extermination.

There are very few women war correspondents. War is a man’s thing. You have to sort of become one of the guys. It was never problem for me, I’ve always lived like a man… Actually, I think… what Michelle really missed… was having a maternal figure in her life… And have to admit… that she was right.
Don’t be so hard on yourself.
…You feel like going?
No… You know what? I´ve heard it already… and it isn’t an evening I’d like to repeat… We all have our own personal apocalypses.
Are you having an awful time with me?
No! I mean him, his lecture. Global crises, the climate change… Hi…
I love your hair.
A good one… even if it was just for one night… Sometimes I think about Damian.
I still think sex is the best way to fend off looming thoughts of death. Like those Spanish Carmelites. Wars turned me into a promiscuous woman, Ingrid.
Good.
Are you still in touch with him?
With who?
With Damian.
I mean… from time to time.
How bad can it get? Well, much worse than you imagine, Damian honey.
Are you all right?
I was trying to write… but I can’t… In this war I’m incapable of writing anything.
And reading? You love to read. You've always been a voracious reader.
I’ve tried it, tried it with some of my favorite writers… but the spell just isn’t there anymore. I’m talking about Faulkner, Hemingway… But I can’t concentrate… my
If you’re too tired, I can read to you.
It’s not just reading, all pleasure’s been reduced. It’s hard to know what I should pay attention to anymore… because I have very little time and I don’t want to waste it.
What about music?
I can only listen to the birds singing.
Well, luckily they give us a serenade every day.
Music decenters me, it comes between me and what I’m doing at that moment, even if it’s just thinking. Maybe the chemo is affecting my hearing.
Oh, honey.
I’ve been reduced to very little of myself. I just long to have some peace of
Talk all you want, I love listening to you.
What are you doing up? What’s wrong?
Your door was closed. I thought you…
Oh, I’m so sorry… I opened the window and the breeze must have closed the door.
I threw up. Oh my God.
Do you think it's fair to be angry with me because I’m still alive?

Take it as a rehearsal. Now you know how it's going to be. This is how you're going to feel. You'll have to make some calls and act out everything we talked about. You don't know anything. We were on vacation.
Please… don't. Stop!
Okay.
So, should we call it a night, or does the ‘young lady’ want to keep watching movies?
Did you tell me they had The Dead... or did I dream that?
Yes… please…
This is too much… harder than I thought it would be. I need to sit.
Here, let me help you.
Ahhh. Much better.
Before coming out here I made a new will.
Let’s not talk about this now.
I’m leaving the apartment and everything in it to Michelle and you.
I found your war journals at the house. What do you want us to do with them? Is it okay if I read them?
Of course you can read them.
Can I tell your story?
You can do what you want. I won’t be here. Can I say that?
No.
Okay.
Let’s not talk about this now, okay? I’ll meet you there.
Hey.
Hi. Everything okay?
Yeah. This breeze is delicious…
Be careful, it’s a little chilly…
So, if you don’t need me, I’m going to go to the gym… But I can stay if you want.
No. Please, go out. I don’t wanna be a downer.
You’re not a downer. You’ve been pretty well behaved.
Have you talked to your trainer about me?

It came up. I told him about being in good shape, when the body keeps fighting to survive… what you told me in the hospital. He looked at me like I was a lunatic, so I told him I had a friend who was sick. That’s all.
Remember you know nothing about anything.
Come here, give me a kiss.
Are you okay?
Yes.
I lied to her. And I don’t like it.

Dear Ingrid, today is such a beautiful day that it seemed to me it was the moment to leave. It consoled me that you weren’t in the room downstairs, even though that was the idea. But you know I always improvise and I’m almost happy that, while I fade away on the lounger, you’re out in the
Oh, Martha… I’ll do everything as you said.
